column6: to hang down
column7: Her long blonde hair fell softly over her shoulders.
column8: She had gorgeous black hair falling down her back, a creamy complexion and a figure models dream of. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

column6: a short letter
column7: He left a note to say he would be home late.^Did you get my note?^There's a note pinned to the door saying when the shop will open again.
column8: Hi Rie Thank you for your note to me! (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

column6: a journey riding a bicycle, motorcycle, or horse
column7: He's gone out for a ride on his bike.^Do you want to come for a ride on my motorbike?
column8: I swam in the sea, sunba[th]ed on the golden beach and had a ride on [a] scooter. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

column6: one of the groups of football teams in a league
column7: the Second Division
column8: I've been playing football for an Italian second division team, by the way. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

column6: to be able to
column7: Can you drive?^She can speak four languages.^I can't read that sign over there - what does it say?
column8: It was difficult to join two words of English correct[l]y. Now I can speak. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali)

column6: an expression on someone's face
column7: She had a worried look about her.^She gave me a questioning look.
column8: China was attacking France, everyone started screaming, and the look of panic on my history teacher['s] face was almost funny. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

column6: not large in size or amount, or not expensive or important
column7: a modest amount of money^They live in a fairly modest house, considering their wealth.^There has been a modest improvement in housing conditions for the poor.^The party made modest gains in the elections, but nothing like the huge gains that were predicted.
column8: Finally, I hope that my modest report will help the management of our college to achieve their aim. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

column6: not having much experience of life and not knowing about the bad things that can happen
column7: an innocent young woman
column8: She is so innocent and doesn't understand anything which is happening around [her]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

column6: to build something again that has been damaged or destroyed
column7: The cathedral was completely rebuilt in 1425 after it had been destroyed by fire.
column8: It's [a] XIX century construction, but they rebuilt it. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

column6: hair that is cut short and straight at the top of someone's face
column7: Her fringe was nearly in her eyes.
column8: She had [a] long fringe over her forehead that almost covered her pale blue eyes. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish)

column6: a type of communication used by the people of a particular country
column7: How many languages do you speak?^I'm hopeless at learning languages.^the English language
column8: I'm learning a new language. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

column6: a thick liquid produced from plants that is used in cooking
column7: olive/sunflower/vegetable oil
column8: Hi Fatima, I think you can bring some potatoes, olive oil and lettuce. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

column6: at this point in a discussion or piece of writing
column7: I don't have time here to go into all the arguments.
column8: My idea here is to highlight the fact that computers are going to control our lives. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

column6: to say that you will certainly give something to someone
column7: They promised us a reward.^ Grandma's ring was promised to me.^Her parents promised her a new car if she passed her exams.
column8: And as a good friend, he has promised me a[n] invitation to [the] wedding. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

column6: to wear a particular type of clothes
column7: I have to dress quite smartly for work.^Patricia always dresses in black.
column8: The waiters dress in national clothes and are very kind. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

column6: when you build something again after it has been damaged or destroyed
column7: The reconstruction of the city took decades.
column8: The classrooms are in need [of] immediate reconstruction. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

column6: a book or course which provides basic knowledge about a subject
column7: an introduction to psychology
column8: Please send me some information about your club and tell me about courses like "[an] introduction to flying". (First Certificate in English; B2; Pass)

column6: why you do something or why something exists
column7: The main purpose of the meeting is to discuss the future of the company. ^ The drug may be legalized for medical purposes. ^a multi-purpose kitchen knife
column8: I think the purpose of it was to make the atmosphere more relax[ed]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

column6: very good
column7: We had a great time at the party.^It was great fun.^I think it's a great idea.
column8: I hope we have a great meal and a lot of fun. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

column6: an area of ground, especially when used for a particular purpose such as farming or building
column7: This sort of land is no good for growing potatoes.^We want to buy a plot of land to build a house.
column8: One man talked about how people can use their land properly, how they [should] take care of their poultry farm or dairy farm, [and] how they can take care of their trees and crops. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish)

column6: Someone who is practical is good at planning things, making sensible decisions and dealing with problems.
column7: She has a lot of interesting ideas but she's not very practical.
column8: But Macon is a practical man, so he tries to find the advantages [of] living on his own. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

column6: a very young child
column7: a baby boy/girl ^baby clothes ^Sandra had a baby on May 29th.
column8: Every day Elisa go[es] to work, make[s] dinner for her little baby and watch[es] the T.V. with her husban[d]. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian)

column6: a conversation between two people, often about a particular subject
column7: He's going to have a talk with his parents and see what they think.
column8: We had a talk and he told me about Bradley and what the band was like. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

column6: an electronic sound made by a telephone
column7: a dialling tone
column8: Quickly, a man got the phone [and was] trying [to] call the police but there was no tone. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

column6: an argument
column7: I don't want to have a fight over this.
column8: I had a fight with my mother and she told me off in front of my friends. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

column6: a program that is secretly put onto a computer in order to destroy the information that is stored on it
column7: My computer has been behaving oddly and I suspect it's a virus.
column8: That document was a "virus" and erased all my documents [o]n my computer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

column6: a building that you can easily recognize, especially one that helps you to know where you are
column7: a historic landmark
column8: What they enjoyed most was the bus tour of London, on Tuesday, as it was a chance for them to see all the famous landmarks without walking. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

column6: to run after someone or something in order to catch them
column7: The dog was chasing a rabbit.^She was chasing after her two-year-old son.
column8: I could feel that the man was chasing after me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

column6: when someone looks at or considers something carefully in order to discover something
column7: a medical examination^I had to have a medical examination when I started my new job.^The evidence is still under examination.^I thought it was paint at first, but on closer examination I realised it was dried blood.
column8: Finally we went to the hospital for a medical examination and fortunately we were all right. (First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan)

column6: an instruction that someone must obey
column7: The soldiers fired as soon as their commander gave the order.^Soldiers must obey orders.
column8: Today I can still remember my last order: "Put that light out!" (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

column6: to think about problems or unpleasant things that might happen in a way that makes you feel anxious
column7: Try not to worry - there's nothing you can do to change the situation.^It's silly worrying about things which are outside your control.
column8: I'm worried about your health. (Key English Test; A2; Farsi)

column6: the spoken form of a full stop in an Internet or email address, or some computer files
column7: What's the web address? "www dot cambridge dot org".

column6: towards the inside or middle of something
column7: He's gone into a shop across the road.^Shall we go into the garden?^Stop running around and get into bed!
column8: I will sweep the floor and clean around my bed, [and] put the waste into the bin. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

column6: as well as the person or thing already mentioned
column7: There is only one other person who could help us.^Are there any other people we should tell?^The product has many other features.^There is no other work available at the moment.
column8: She likes meeting other people because she wants [to] improve her English. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Nepali)

column6: independent and not supporting any side in an argument, fight, or competition
column7: neutral ground/territory^ He decided to remain/stay neutral on the issue.
column8: Thus, its main advantage is that the information you get is not provided by a company or something like that but by a neutral person. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

column6: to not allow people to use something because it is only for a particular person or for a particular purpose
column7: This space is reserved for ambulances only.^These seats are reserved for the elderly and women with babies.
column8: We will have free tent accom[m]odation in an area reserved for the staff. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

column6: to turn part of your body to face a different direction
column7: She twisted her head so she could see what was happening.
column8: Through the right wing of the car I could [see] his eyes glitter like two flawless diamonds as he twisted his neck slightly from time to time to beam at me. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

column6: Formal education, training, etc. happens through studying rather than working in a job.
column7: Tom had little formal schooling.
column8: I never had any formal training in computers but I know how to operate the system, to make files and to use [the] internet. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi)
